title: Asparagine biosynthesis as a mechanism of increased host lethality induced by Serratia marcescens in simulated microgravity environments
background: Spaceflight conditions can increase pathogenicity of microbes, converting opportunistic pathogens to primary pathogens that pose threats to astronauts with potentially compromised immune systems during missions.
objective: Evaluate the mechanism for increased virulence of opportunistic pathogen Serratia marcescens in simulated microgravity and identify potential countermeasures.
methods: Low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) using rotating wall vessel, Drosophila melanogaster infection model, gene expression analysis via qPCR, amino acid quantification, L-asparaginase treatment, and survival analysis.
results: LSMMG increased asparagine uptake and synthesis with 39.17-fold upregulation of asnB gene. Addition of both aspartate and glutamine recapitulated increased host lethality. L-asparaginase effectively mitigated LSMMG-induced virulence.
conclusion: Asparagine utilization pathway underlies increased mortality from microgravity-treated S. marcescens, and L-asparaginase provides a potential therapeutic countermeasure for spaceflight infections.

learning_notes.note: Low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) using rotating wall vessels at 25 rpm effectively simulates spaceflight conditions by keeping cells in continuous suspension, creating a low fluid shear environment that recapitulates key biological responses observed in actual spaceflight experiments with pathogens.

Serratia marcescens exposed to LSMMG showed a dramatic 39.17-fold upregulation of the asnB gene (asparagine synthetase B), which catalyzes asparagine synthesis from aspartate and glutamine, indicating a fundamental shift in amino acid metabolism under microgravity conditions.

The increased virulence in LSMMG-treated bacteria requires both aspartate and glutamine substrates - while aspartate alone increased bacterial growth rate, only the combination of both amino acids induced maximal asnB expression and host mortality, showing that growth rate alone doesn't determine virulence.

L-asparaginase treatment effectively counteracted LSMMG-induced virulence, reducing both bacterial growth in culture and host mortality in infected Drosophila, with risk ratios showing 2.92-fold reduction in death rate, providing a promising therapeutic approach for spaceflight infections.

The Drosophila melanogaster model proved highly effective for space-relevant host-pathogen studies due to its well-characterized innate immune system, genetic tractability, short life cycle, low resource requirements, and genetic homology to mammalian systems - advantages particularly valuable for spaceflight constraints.

LSMMG-treated S. marcescens consumed extracellular asparagine and glutamine significantly faster during the active growth phase (6 hours) compared to controls, with F-values of 1540.68 and 282.056 respectively, indicating enhanced nutrient competition capabilities under microgravity.

The study demonstrates that microgravity specifically enhances bacterial ability to compete with host immune cells for critical amino acids, particularly asparagine, which serves both bacterial growth needs and can suppress host T-cell responses, creating a dual advantage for pathogens in spaceflight conditions.
